skos.definition: Acute kidney injury caused by direct damage to the renal parenchyma, including tubules, glomeruli, interstitium, or vasculature, characterized by impaired tubular function and typically prolonged recovery compared to pre-renal AKI.
skos.scopeNote: Accounts for 25-40% of AKI cases; acute tubular necrosis (ATN) is the most common subtype

ICD_10.description: Acute kidney failure with tubular necrosis

content.title: Intrinsic Acute Kidney Injury
content.summary: Intrinsic AKI results from direct damage to kidney parenchyma, most commonly affecting the tubules (ATN) but also including glomerular, interstitial, and vascular etiologies. Unlike pre-renal AKI, tubular function is impaired, leading to characteristic urinary findings and typically slower recovery.
key_points: ATN (acute tubular necrosis) is the most common form of intrinsic AKI
Muddy brown granular casts are pathognomonic for ATN
FENa >2% indicates impaired tubular sodium reabsorption
Urine osmolality approaches plasma (~300-350 mOsm/kg) - isosthenuric
Ischemic and nephrotoxic ATN are the two main subtypes
Recovery takes 1-3 weeks with supportive care
No specific therapy; avoid further nephrotoxic insults
content.statement: Intrinsic acute kidney injury represents structural damage to the kidney parenchyma, most commonly manifesting as acute tubular necrosis from ischemia or nephrotoxins. Loss of tubular function results in impaired sodium reabsorption and urine concentrating ability, producing characteristic laboratory findings that distinguish it from pre-renal AKI.

explanation.intuition: Think of intrinsic AKI as the kidney suffering actual 'damage' rather than just 'stress.' When tubular cells die or become dysfunctional, they can no longer reabsorb sodium or concentrate urine properly. The dead cells slough off and form the characteristic muddy brown casts seen in urine microscopy.
explanation.key_insight: The hallmark of intrinsic AKI is loss of tubular function - the kidney cannot concentrate urine or reabsorb sodium even when volume depleted. This distinguishes it from pre-renal AKI where tubular function is preserved. Urinary indices reflect this impaired tubular function (FENa >2%, dilute urine).
explanation.technical_details: In ischemic ATN, prolonged hypoperfusion leads to ATP depletion in tubular epithelial cells, causing loss of cell polarity, tight junction disruption, and cell death. Nephrotoxic ATN occurs from direct toxicity to tubular cells. The S3 segment of the proximal tubule and medullary thick ascending limb are most vulnerable due to high metabolic activity and relative hypoxia. Recovery requires tubular cell regeneration from surviving cells.

definitions_glossary.acute_tubular_necrosis: Death of renal tubular epithelial cells due to ischemia or nephrotoxins; most common cause of intrinsic AKI
definitions_glossary.muddy_brown_casts: Granular urinary casts with brown pigmentation from degenerating tubular cells; pathognomonic for ATN
definitions_glossary.ischemic_ATN: Tubular necrosis resulting from prolonged renal hypoperfusion, often following severe pre-renal AKI
definitions_glossary.nephrotoxic_ATN: Tubular necrosis caused by direct toxic effects of drugs, contrast, or endogenous substances
definitions_glossary.tubular_epithelial_cells: Cells lining the renal tubules responsible for reabsorption and secretion functions
definitions_glossary.fractional_excretion_sodium: FENa >2% in intrinsic AKI indicates impaired tubular sodium reabsorption
definitions_glossary.isosthenuria: Urine osmolality equal to plasma (~300 mOsm/kg) indicating loss of concentrating ability
definitions_glossary.acute_interstitial_nephritis: Inflammatory condition of renal interstitium, often drug-induced; a cause of intrinsic AKI
definitions_glossary.glomerulonephritis: Inflammatory disease of glomeruli; can cause intrinsic AKI with nephritic syndrome
definitions_glossary.renal_tubular_cell_regeneration: Process by which surviving tubular cells proliferate to replace necrotic cells during recovery
definitions_glossary.aminoglycoside_nephrotoxicity: Dose-dependent tubular toxicity from aminoglycoside antibiotics; classic cause of nephrotoxic ATN
definitions_glossary.contrast_induced_nephropathy: AKI occurring within 48-72 hours of iodinated contrast exposure
definitions_glossary.rhabdomyolysis: Skeletal muscle breakdown releasing myoglobin causing pigment nephropathy and ATN
definitions_glossary.cast_nephropathy: Tubular obstruction by precipitated light chains in multiple myeloma

pathophysiology.mechanism: Direct damage to renal parenchyma leads to tubular cell dysfunction and death. In ischemic ATN, ATP depletion causes loss of Na+/K+-ATPase polarity, cytoskeletal disruption, and apoptosis/necrosis. In nephrotoxic ATN, toxins directly damage tubular cells or cause vasoconstriction.

anatomic_sites.tubular: ATN - most common; affects proximal tubule S3 segment and thick ascending limb
anatomic_sites.glomerular: Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis, anti-GBM disease, lupus nephritis
anatomic_sites.vascular: Thrombotic microangiopathy, atheroembolic disease, renal artery thrombosis

phases_of_ATN.initiation: Hours to days - initial injury with declining GFR
phases_of_ATN.extension: Days - ongoing injury, inflammation, cell death
phases_of_ATN.maintenance: 1-2 weeks - stable low GFR, may require dialysis
phases_of_ATN.recovery: Weeks to months - tubular regeneration, improving GFR

symptoms: Symptoms of underlying cause (infection, rash, etc.)

imaging: Renal ultrasound: normal size, increased echogenicity
Normal renal blood flow on Doppler (unless vascular cause)
biopsy_indications: Suspected acute interstitial nephritis not responding to steroid trial

general_principles: Supportive care - no specific ATN therapy proven
Optimize volume status (avoid hypo- and hypervolemia)
Adjust medication dosing for reduced GFR

specific_therapies.ATN: Supportive care only; loop diuretics for volume overload (do not improve outcomes)
specific_therapies.AIN: Remove offending drug; consider corticosteroids if no improvement

renal_replacement_therapy.indications: AEIOU - Acidosis, Electrolytes (hyperkalemia), Intoxication, Overload, Uremia
renal_replacement_therapy.modalities: Intermittent hemodialysis, CRRT for hemodynamically unstable patients
renal_replacement_therapy.duration: Until native kidney recovery or determination of permanent failure

prognosis.residual_CKD: 25-30% have incomplete recovery with residual CKD
prognosis.mortality: In-hospital mortality 20-50% depending on ICU setting and comorbidities

learning_objectives: Define intrinsic AKI and classify its anatomic subtypes
Describe the pathophysiology of acute tubular necrosis
Interpret urinary indices to distinguish intrinsic from pre-renal AKI
Recognize characteristic urinary sediment findings for different intrinsic causes
List common ischemic and nephrotoxic causes of ATN
Outline management principles and indications for renal replacement therapy
clinical_pearls: Muddy brown casts are the 'smoking gun' for ATN - always examine urine sediment
FENa can be <1% in early contrast nephropathy, myoglobinuria, and pigment nephropathy
Non-oliguric ATN has better prognosis than oliguric ATN
Drug-induced AIN: think eosinophils in urine, fever, rash, peripheral eosinophilia
RBC casts indicate glomerulonephritis - pursue urgent workup (ANCA, anti-GBM, complement)
Aminoglycoside nephrotoxicity typically occurs after 5-7 days of therapy

common_question_stems: Post-operative patient with oliguria and muddy brown casts
Patient on gentamicin for 10 days develops rising creatinine
ICU patient with sepsis now with FENa 3.5%
Patient on NSAID develops AKI with eosinophiluria
exam_tips: Intrinsic = impaired concentrating ability (urine osm ~300) + dilute sodium (FENa >2%)
Muddy brown casts = ATN; RBC casts = GN; WBC casts = pyelonephritis/AIN

teaching_cases.scenario: 68-year-old man 5 days post-cardiac surgery with oliguria, Cr 4.2 mg/dL (baseline 1.1)
teaching_cases.key_findings: Urine microscopy shows muddy brown granular casts, FENa 4.2%, urine sodium 55 mEq/L
teaching_cases.diagnosis: Ischemic acute tubular necrosis from intraoperative hypotension
teaching_cases.management: Supportive care, optimize volume, avoid nephrotoxins, dialysis if indicated

citations.authors: Bellomo R, Kellum JA, Ronco C
citations.title: Acute kidney injury

evidence.confidence_rationale: Based on KDIGO guidelines and comprehensive nephrology literature

sources.source: KDIGO Clinical Practice Guideline for Acute Kidney Injury
sources.relevance: Primary reference for AKI classification and management

sources.source: Brenner and Rector's The Kidney, 11th Edition
